itunes.subtitle: Merry Christmas (for those who celebrate)! Happy Holidays. And Welcome to all! It is December 25. We have a very special episode of the Stitch Please podcast. Lisa is joined by her mother and her two younger sisters as they discuss their mother's Christmas sewing and overall amazing creativity.  Tune in as they share memories of past Christmases and kee-kee over youthful shenanigans! And find out who is waaaay beyond receiving gifts for Christmas. Spoiler alert: it is NOT Lisa.

itunes.author: Lisa Woolfork
itunes.keywords: sewing, black women, quilting, stitch, creatives, stitching, african american, fashion, holiday crafts, womanism, blacklivesmatter, quilt, sew, christmas crafts
itunes.subtitle: Linda Nance of Gotta Be Handmade is a deeply creative spirit. And now that she is in retirement, she is claiming her time. She took a deep dive into learning social media practices. Now, she promotes other creatives through her blog and video interviews. She and Lisa talk about her special ornaments with a story and the anatomy of a South Carolina pine cone. She also shares a moonshine based home-remedy that sounds like a pretty good winter cocktail.
itunes.summary: Linda Nance of Gotta Be Handmade is a deeply creative spirit. And now that she is in retirement, she is claiming her time. She took a deep dive into learning social media practices. She also shares a moonshine based home-remedy that sounds like a pretty good winter cocktail.

Clover Curved Ruler set
Upgrade You
TG1600pro
Zirkel
Felt Pressing Mat
Scissors
 
Sewist-to-Sewist Gift Ideas
Fast Fit by Sandra Betzina
Fitting and Pattern Alterations (this is used in design schools, hence the $ but it's excellent)
Pants for Real People
Reader's Digest Complete Guide to Sewing 1976 edition -- This is a rare gem of a book. If you find one at an estate or yard sale, snap it up! Otherwise, it is here. :)
Supplies for a GIFT KIT include...
Appleton Dress – a favorite Black Women Stitch dress
PDF Plotting—Save your sanity! NEVER tape a PDF pattern again. Buy the A0 format and print it with PDF Plotting.

itunes.keywords: sewing, black women, quilting, stitch, stitching, african american, fashion, womanism, blacklivesmatter, quilt, sew
itunes.subtitle:
Gift ideas for the newbie or advanced sewist. Sewist, Attorney, and Black Women Stitch OG Allysia Holland joins Lisa for a chat about good gifts to put on your holiday/birthday/anyday wish list. We also review TWO Oliso irons: the Oliso Pro TG 1600 and the Oliso M2 Mini Project Iron. And speaking of "GIFT" guide, thanks to Oliso, we are having a GIVEAWAY!  The winner will be announced TODAY in this episode. The winner's name will be posted later on the Black Women Stitch IG page and contacted directly too. 
 Links to products included in the show notes.

itunes.author: Lisa Woolfork
itunes.keywords: sewing, black women, quilting, stitch, stitching, african american, fashion, womanism, blacklivesmatter, quilt, sew
itunes.subtitle: Alethia Hudson is a fashion designer, sewing instructor, and curator of a 10,000 member Facebook sewing group. She and Lisa chat about building a stitching community online and in real life. Alethia's sewing retreats (the next one is July 2020) are an excellent example of stitching a community together. Lisa and Alethia also discuss the changes at JoAnn's Fabrics and what constitutes an "emergency sewing situation."
itunes.summary: Alethia Hudson is a fashion designer, sewing instructor, and curator of a 10,000 member Facebook sewing group. She and Lisa chat about building a stitching community online and in real life. Alethia's sewing retreats (the next one is July 2020) are an excellent example of stitching a community together. Lisa and Alethia also discuss the changes at JoAnn's Fabrics and what constitutes an "emergency sewing situation."

items.title: Sew Much Talent with Alethia Hudson

itunes.author: Lisa Woolfork
itunes.keywords: sewing, black women, quilting, stitch, stitching, african american, fashion, womanism, blacklivesmatter, quilt, sew
itunes.subtitle: Welcome to our special BLACKER FRIDAY episode! Black Women Stitch recognizes the structural inequities that disproportionally impact black women, girls, and femmes. The wage/income gap for Black women is a staggering example of how racism and sexism combine to do harm. But rather than give you an economic analysis that you could easily find on your own, we are doing our part to elevate black women owned sewing and crafting businesses. In this episode, we center the voices of Black women makers as they talk about their work. So. When you’re shopping next week for Black Friday, Small Business Saturday, and Cyber Monday, remember these creative ventures and #payblackwomen
itunes.summary: Welcome to our special BLACKER FRIDAY episode! Black Women Stitch recognizes the structural inequities that disproportionally impact black women, girls, and femmes. The wage/income gap for Black women is a staggering example of how racism and sexism combine to do harm. But rather than give you an economic analysis that you could easily find on your own, we are doing our part to elevate black women owned sewing and crafting businesses. In this episode, we center the voices of Black women makers as they talk about their work. So. When you’re shopping next week for Black Friday, Small Business Saturday, and Cyber Monday, remember these creative ventures and #payblackwomen

items.title: BLACKER FRIDAY

itunes.author: Lisa Woolfork
itunes.keywords: sewing, black women, quilting, stitch, nude, illusion fabric, stitching, african american, mesh fabric, black ballerinas, black dancers, nude fabric, fashion, sheer fabrics, womanism, blacklivesmatter, quilt, sew, dancewear
itunes.subtitle: Natasha Clute is a owner of Ta-osh Designs, a company specializing in custom sewing including dancewear and other beautifully elaborate costumes with the illusion of skin. In addition to offering travel sewing services and alterations, Natasha has revolutionized what it means for black women sewists to be able to select "nude" fabrics that actually match our skin.
itunes.summary: Natasha Clute is a owner of Ta-osh Designs, a company specializing in custom sewing including dancewear and other beautifully elaborate costumes with the illusion of skin. In addition to offering travel sewing services and alterations, Natasha has revolutionized what it means for black women sewists to be able to select "nude" fabrics that actually match our skin.

items.title: Nude for Who?: Sheer Stretch Fabrics with Melanin

itunes.keywords: sewing, black women, quilting, stitch, stitching, african american, whiteness, crayons, fashion, white privelige, womanism, blacklivesmatter, quilt, sew
itunes.subtitle: A brief discussion of the ways that Crayola's "flesh" colored crayon (from back in the day) is part of the larger problem of centering and naturalizing whiteness as the default position in America. From Band Aids to Breathe Rite strips to drugstore lipsticks, black folx struggle to find "nude" shades that are not a lie. Nude fabrics are a similar problem.
itunes.summary: A brief discussion of the ways that Crayola's "flesh" colored crayon (from back in the day) is part of the larger problem of centering and naturalizing whiteness as the default position in America. From Band Aids to Breathe Rite strips to drugstore lipsticks, black folx struggle to find "nude" shades that are not a lie. Nude fabrics are a similar problem.

items.title: That "Flesh" Colored Crayon and Other Fake Nudes

items.author: woolfork@gmail.com (Queenora Irvin)
items.content:
Visit Finer Fabrics between 9/17 and 10/8 to preorder the African Inspired knit fabric collection: https://queenorascloset.com/collections/finer-fabrics-by-queenora

Additional References:

Queenora was inspired by TipStitched to start sewing https://tipstitched.com/

Capitol Chic Designs is an example of black women creatives choosing to center themselves in their own experience rather than center whiteness. https://capitolchicdesigns.com/

On the first episode of The Tamron Hall Show, Tamron talked about the challenges she faced as a black woman in daytime TV, specifically the concern that white women would not watch a black woman in the daytime slot. https://www.glamour.com/story/tamron-hall-interview

Suggestions for further inquiry.

Why are maternal outcomes are comparatively dire for Black women in the US? https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1595019/

Juneteenth. https://www.juneteenth.com/index.html

White fragility. --- If you don't know what this is, now is a great time to Google.

itunes.author: Lisa Woolfork
itunes.subtitle: The inaugural episode of Stitch Please, the Black Women Stitch podcast. This episode explores the origins of Lisa's Back to School sewing tradition including the ways that sewing is a symbol of and shorthand for "love." Episode includes two very special guests: Lisa's sons sharing their opinions of the tradition they grew up with.
itunes.summary: The inaugural episode of Stitch Please, the Black Women Stitch podcast. This episode explores the origins of Lisa's Back to School sewing tradition including the ways that sewing is a symbol of and shorthand for "love." Episode includes two very special guests: Lisa's sons sharing their opinions of the tradition they grew up with.

items.title: Introducing Stitch Please, the Black Women Stitch Podcast

itunes.author: Lisa Woolfork
itunes.summary:
Dive deep into the vibrant world of sewing with the Stitch Please podcast, an official show of Black Women Stitch – the sewing group where Black lives matter. Uniquely crafted for those who love sewing, this sewing podcast is a gem that centers around Black women, girls, and femmes, weaving threads of creativity, technique, and passion with every episode.

Hosted by Lisa Woolfork, a 6th generation sewing enthusiast, this podcast not only mirrors her ardor for the craft but also her roles as an artist, activist, and academic. Specializing in African American literature and culture, Lisa seamlessly stitches together her varied backgrounds to produce episodes that are both informative and engaging. You'll be immersed in lively interviews that are enriched by her expertise, presenting a fresh perspective that few other podcasts in the sewing community can offer.

As an artist, Lisa Woolfork brings a unique eye for detail and aesthetics, offering listeners the chance to envision sewing in new, vibrant ways. As an activist, she ensures that the podcast sewing narratives and discussions are rooted in liberation, particularly emphasizing the significance of Black lives. Her academic background adds another layer of depth to the podcast, allowing listeners to delve into the rich tapestry of African American literature and culture, shedding light on how these narratives can influence and inspire one's sewing journey.

Each week, listeners of the Stitch Please podcast can look forward to insightful discussions that celebrate Black creativity in sewing and quilting. Moreover, as a bonus, this sewing podcast shares invaluable tips and techniques, making it a must-listen for both beginners and seasoned sewists alike.

Join us as we thread the needle of history, art, and activism with the love of sewing, creating a tapestry of stories and tips that resonate with every stitch. If you cherish the world of sewing, quilting, and the rich narratives of Black creativity, the Stitch Please podcast is your ideal companion. Tune in weekly. This sewing podcast will “help you get your stitch together.”

title: Stitch Please
